canvases.label: Holograph Notes on Scottish Songs, f.16r

metadata.value: 12 folio pages in the hand of Robert Burns, which were brought to prominence in 1922 by Davidson Cook, who transcribed and published these pages as _Annotations of Scottish Songs by Burns: An Essential Supplement to Cromek and Dick_. Davidson’s title refers to Robert H. Cromek’s _The Reliques of Robert Burns: Consisting of Original Letters, Poems, and Critical Observations_ (1808) and J. C. Dick’s_Notes on Scottish Song by Robert Burns_ (1908). Cook makes clear that these folio pages were an unnamed source for Dick in particular, and Cook transcribes many notes listed as garbled, unreadable, or spurious by Dick. This is page 1 of the folio. Burns discusses two songs, “Waukin o’ the Fauld” and “Mill Mill O”. What appears to be the title of a third song, “Maggie Lauder”, is written on this sheet between “Waukin o’ the Fauld” and “Mill Mill O” with space left for further writing, but nothing more than that has been recorded. Of “Waukin o’ the Fauld” , Burns says that there are “two stanzas still sung to this tune” and he believes this song to be the original that inspired Ramsay’s song of the same name in “Gentle Shepherd”. Burns records the first two lines of the song, and then states: “I regret that, as in many of our old songs, the delicacy of this old fragment is not equal to its wit and humor.” Of “Mill Mill O”, Burns records a stanza and chorus from what he believes to the original. He then states that “The remaining two stanzas, though pretty enough, partake rather too much of the rude simplicity of the ‘olden time’ to be admitted here.”
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Holograph Notes on Scottish Songs, f.17r

metadata.value: 12 folio pages in the hand of Robert Burns, which were brought to prominence in 1922 by Davidson Cook, who transcribed and published these pages as _Annotations of Scottish Songs by Burns: An Essential Supplement to Cromek and Dick_. Davidson’s title refers to Robert H. Cromek’s _The Reliques of Robert Burns: Consisting of Original Letters, Poems, and Critical Observations_ (1808) and J. C. Dick’s_Notes on Scottish Song by Robert Burns_ (1908). Cook makes clear that these folio pages were an unnamed source for Dick in particular, and Cook transcribes many notes listed as garbled, unreadable, or spurious by Dick. This is page 3 of the folio. It discusses the song “Kirk wad let me be”. In western Scotland, Burns says that the song is said to have once “saved a covenanting Clergyman out of a scrape” prior to the Revolution when “being a Scots Covenanter was being a Felon”. Mass. John fell into the hands of some soldiers who suspected that he might be a member of the Clergy. John is said to have “assumed a freedom of manners (very unlike the gloomy strictness of his sect)”, which included singing, and in some accounts, even composing, “Kirk wad let me be”. The soldiers “swore he was a d—d honest fellow & that it was impossible he could belong to these hellish conventicles, & so gave him his liberty”. Burns then explains that the first stanza of the song is a favourite dramatic interlude in south-west country weddings. It describes a “young fellow” dressed as an “old beggar”. The description of the tradition continues on page 4.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Holograph Notes on Scottish Songs, f.18r

metadata.value: 12 folio pages in the hand of Robert Burns, which were brought to prominence in 1922 by Davidson Cook, who transcribed and published these pages as _Annotations of Scottish Songs by Burns: An Essential Supplement to Cromek and Dick_. Davidson’s title refers to Robert H. Cromek’s _The Reliques of Robert Burns: Consisting of Original Letters, Poems, and Critical Observations_ (1808) and J. C. Dick’s_Notes on Scottish Song by Robert Burns_ (1908). Cook makes clear that these folio pages were an unnamed source for Dick in particular, and Cook transcribes many notes listed as garbled, unreadable, or spurious by Dick. This is page 5 of the folio. It records four songs: “Wat ye what my Minnie did”, “If ever I marry, I’ll marry a wright”, “Lass, an’ I come near ye” and “Little wats thou o’ thy daddie, hiney”. Next to “If ever I marry”, Burns has noted “(See this tune in Oswald)”. Next to “Lass, an’ I come near ye”, he has written “(See this tune in Aird’s ‘selection of airs and marches’)”. And next to “Little wats though o’ thy daddie, hiney”, he has noted that it is “(sometimes called Elsie Marley)”.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Holograph Notes on Scottish Songs, f.19r

metadata.value: 12 folio pages in the hand of Robert Burns, which were brought to prominence in 1922 by Davidson Cook, who transcribed and published these pages as _Annotations of Scottish Songs by Burns: An Essential Supplement to Cromek and Dick_. Davidson’s title refers to Robert H. Cromek’s _The Reliques of Robert Burns: Consisting of Original Letters, Poems, and Critical Observations_ (1808) and J. C. Dick’s_Notes on Scottish Song by Robert Burns_ (1908). Cook makes clear that these folio pages were an unnamed source for Dick in particular, and Cook transcribes many notes listed as garbled, unreadable, or spurious by Dick. This is page 7 of the folio. This page records two songs: “The Posie” and “Saw ye nae my Peggy”. Continuing from page 6, Burns suggest that Oswald borrowed the first three bars of “The Posie” for his “Roslin Castle”. It is the tune of the song that Burns seems most interested in, as he states that “The old verses to which it [the tune] was sung, when I took notes from a country girl’s voice, had no great merit”. Regarding “Saw ye nae my Peggy”, Burns notes that it is a song familiar to most Scots and he records what he believes to be the original words. Lines continue on Page 8.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Holograph Notes on Scottish Songs, f.20r

metadata.value: 12 folio pages in the hand of Robert Burns, which were brought to prominence in 1922 by Davidson Cook, who transcribed and published these pages as _Annotations of Scottish Songs by Burns: An Essential Supplement to Cromek and Dick_. Davidson’s title refers to Robert H. Cromek’s _The Reliques of Robert Burns: Consisting of Original Letters, Poems, and Critical Observations_ (1808) and J. C. Dick’s_Notes on Scottish Song by Robert Burns_ (1908). Cook makes clear that these folio pages were an unnamed source for Dick in particular, and Cook transcribes many notes listed as garbled, unreadable, or spurious by Dick. This is page 9 of the folio. This page discusses two songs: “The lass of Liviston” and “The lass o’ Patie’s Mill”. Regarding “The lass of Liviston”, Burns only records four lines, stating that “The old song, in three eight-line stanzas, is well known, and has merit as to wit and humour; but is rather unfit for insertion”. Regarding “The lass o’ Patie’s Mill”, Burns records no lines, but states that this song has been variously claimed by Ayrshire and by a Clergyman of Galston. Burns says that his “much-esteemed friend Sir William Cunningham of Robertland” was told by the “late John, Earl of Loudon” that Allan Ramsay wrote the song for the then Earl of Loudon at Loudon Castle. The two men reportedly saw a woman at Patie’s Mill on the banks of the Irvine “Tedding o’ the hay”, which inspired the song. Burns accepts this story as fact.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Holograph Notes on Scottish Songs, f.21r

metadata.value: 12 folio pages in the hand of Robert Burns, which were brought to prominence in 1922 by Davidson Cook, who transcribed and published these pages as _Annotations of Scottish Songs by Burns: An Essential Supplement to Cromek and Dick_. Davidson’s title refers to Robert H. Cromek’s _The Reliques of Robert Burns: Consisting of Original Letters, Poems, and Critical Observations_ (1808) and J. C. Dick’s_Notes on Scottish Song by Robert Burns_ (1908). Cook makes clear that these folio pages were an unnamed source for Dick in particular, and Cook transcribes many notes listed as garbled, unreadable, or spurious by Dick. This is page 11 of the folio. At the top of the page, a note carries on a discussion of “Highland Laddie”, stating that Dr Arne has a variation called “The new Highland Laddie”. The rest of the page discusses three songs: “Clout the Cauldron”, “Auld Lang Syne”, and “Dainty Davie”. Burns relates that “Clout the Cauldron” is thought to be connected to a song composed by one of the “Kenmure family, in the Cavalier times” as he hid under the disguise of a tinker. Burns references an alternate title of “The Blacksmith and his Apron”. For “Auld Lang Syne”, no lines are recorded, but Burns says that Ramsay took the first line of the song from a fragment that can “be seen in the _Museum_, vol. V.” “Dainty Daisy” is said to tell the tale of Rev. David Williamson. Lady Cherrytrees passed Williamson as a lady to dragoons searching for him as a result of his adherence to the Solemn League and Covenant. However, she did so by passing him as her daughter’s bed-fellow, and, during this ruse, Williamson impregnated the Lady’s daughter. Lines and further discussion are recorded on page 12.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Holograph Notes on Scottish Songs, f.16v

metadata.value: 12 folio pages in the hand of Robert Burns, which were brought to prominence in 1922 by Davidson Cook, who transcribed and published these pages as _Annotations of Scottish Songs by Burns: An Essential Supplement to Cromek and Dick_. Davidson’s title refers to Robert H. Cromek’s _The Reliques of Robert Burns: Consisting of Original Letters, Poems, and Critical Observations_ (1808) and J. C. Dick’s_Notes on Scottish Song by Robert Burns_ (1908). Cook makes clear that these folio pages were an unnamed source for Dick in particular, and Cook transcribes many notes listed as garbled, unreadable, or spurious by Dick. This is page 2 of the folio. Burns records two songs, “Bob o’ Dumblane” and “O’er the Muir amang the Heather”. What appears to be the title of a third song, “The Moudiewort”, is written at the bottom of the page, but nothing more than that has been recorded. Of “Bob o’ Dumblane,” Burns says that Ramsay has modernized the song. Burns therefore records two stanzas of what he takes as the original, which he said he “learned on the spot from my Hostess in the principal Inn there”. Burns then recounts an anecdote which he says he has “heard well authenticated”. In this story, “a Scots officer in Argyle’s army observed to His Grace that he was afraid the rebels would give out to the world that they had gotten the victory. ‘Weel, weel,’ returned His Grace, alluding to the foregoing ballad; ‘if they think it be na weel bobbit, we’ll bob it again.’” For “O’er the Muir amang the heather”, Burns simply records the first stanza.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Holograph Notes on Scottish Songs, f.17v

metadata.value: 12 folio pages in the hand of Robert Burns, which were brought to prominence in 1922 by Davidson Cook, who transcribed and published these pages as _Annotations of Scottish Songs by Burns: An Essential Supplement to Cromek and Dick_. Davidson’s title refers to Robert H. Cromek’s _The Reliques of Robert Burns: Consisting of Original Letters, Poems, and Critical Observations_ (1808) and J. C. Dick’s_Notes on Scottish Song by Robert Burns_ (1908). Cook makes clear that these folio pages were an unnamed source for Dick in particular, and Cook transcribes many notes listed as garbled, unreadable, or spurious by Dick. This is page 4 of the folio. This page continues a description of a south-west Scottish wedding tradition connected to the song “Kirk wad let me be”. A young fellow would be dressed “like an old beggar” and brought into the wedding house. He would then sing an altered version of the first stanza from “Kirk wad let me be” before being persuaded to drink and dance comically to “Auld Glenae” played on fiddle. He would become increasingly wild, until at last carried out supposedly “dead-drunk”. Burns also includes a note on Glenae, explaining it is “on the small river Ae, in Annandale; the seat and designation of an ancient branch, and the present representative of the gallant, but unfortunate, Dalziels of Carnwath”.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Holograph Notes on Scottish Songs, f.18v

metadata.value: 12 folio pages in the hand of Robert Burns, which were brought to prominence in 1922 by Davidson Cook, who transcribed and published these pages as _Annotations of Scottish Songs by Burns: An Essential Supplement to Cromek and Dick_. Davidson’s title refers to Robert H. Cromek’s _The Reliques of Robert Burns: Consisting of Original Letters, Poems, and Critical Observations_ (1808) and J. C. Dick’s_Notes on Scottish Song by Robert Burns_ (1908). Cook makes clear that these folio pages were an unnamed source for Dick in particular, and Cook transcribes many notes listed as garbled, unreadable, or spurious by Dick. This is page 6 of the folio. This page discusses five songs. “The King o’ France he rade a race” is recorded with a note stating “(Oswald & Macgibbon’s Collections, now altered into a modern reel called The lass o’ Loncarty)”. “Rob shoor in hairst” is recorded with a note “(See this tune in Oswald’s and other Collections.)” Without recording any lines, Burns states that the song “Jockie’s gray breeks” seems to be “a Scotish air, yet there is a well-known tune and song in the North of Ireland, call’d ‘The weaver and his shuttle, O,’ which though sung much quicker, is, every note, the very tune”. Burns records the chorus of “Corn rigs are boni”, saying that it was all he could “meet of the old words”. Finally, Burns states that he believes that Oswald’s “Roslin Castle” was modulated from an older song, “The Posie”. Further discussion of this song continues on page 7.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Holograph Notes on Scottish Songs, f.19v

metadata.value: 12 folio pages in the hand of Robert Burns, which were brought to prominence in 1922 by Davidson Cook, who transcribed and published these pages as _Annotations of Scottish Songs by Burns: An Essential Supplement to Cromek and Dick_. Davidson’s title refers to Robert H. Cromek’s _The Reliques of Robert Burns: Consisting of Original Letters, Poems, and Critical Observations_ (1808) and J. C. Dick’s_Notes on Scottish Song by Robert Burns_ (1908). Cook makes clear that these folio pages were an unnamed source for Dick in particular, and Cook transcribes many notes listed as garbled, unreadable, or spurious by Dick. This is page 8 of the folio. Continuing from Page 7, lines from “Saw ye nae my Peggy” are recorded. Burns states that he believes these recorded lines to the original ones. He states that Ramsay has different lines recorded but Ramsay’s lines are “never to be met with in the fireside circle of our peasantry; while, what I take to be the old song is in every shepherd’s mouth. Ramsay, I suppose, had thought the old verses unworthy of a place in his Collection.” Lines from “Fy, gar rub her o’er wi’ stre” are then recorded, along with Burns’ note that “It is self-evident that the first four lines are part of a song much ancienter than Ramsay’s beautiful verses which are annexed to them. To this day, among people who know nothing of Ramsay’s verse, the following is the song , and all the song that ever I heard”.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Holograph Notes on Scottish Songs, f.20v

metadata.value: 12 folio pages in the hand of Robert Burns, which were brought to prominence in 1922 by Davidson Cook, who transcribed and published these pages as _Annotations of Scottish Songs by Burns: An Essential Supplement to Cromek and Dick_. Davidson’s title refers to Robert H. Cromek’s _The Reliques of Robert Burns: Consisting of Original Letters, Poems, and Critical Observations_ (1808) and J. C. Dick’s_Notes on Scottish Song by Robert Burns_ (1908). Cook makes clear that these folio pages were an unnamed source for Dick in particular, and Cook transcribes many notes listed as garbled, unreadable, or spurious by Dick. This is page 10 of the folio. This page discusses the song “Highland Laddie”. Burns reports that there are “several airs and songs of that name”, but says that he takes the oldest to be one that Oswald recorded under the title of “The auld Highland laddie”. Another four- or five-stanza version, which is said to predate Jacobite times, goes by the title “Jinglan Johnie”. A three-stanza version under the title “Highland Laddie” is referenced and said to have been recorded by Ramsay. A “Highland Laddie” is also said to exist that is made up of “the tune of several Jacobite fragments”. At the top of page 10, a pencil note has been added, most likely by an archival reader, referencing a song called “The Highlander’s Prayer” On page 11 of the folio, Burns concludes his discussion of “Highland Laddie” by stating that “Another of this name is Dr Arne’s beautiful air, called “The new Highland Laddie”.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Holograph Notes on Scottish Songs, f.21v

metadata.value: 12 folio pages in the hand of Robert Burns, which were brought to prominence in 1922 by Davidson Cook, who transcribed and published these pages as _Annotations of Scottish Songs by Burns: An Essential Supplement to Cromek and Dick_. Davidson’s title refers to Robert H. Cromek’s _The Reliques of Robert Burns: Consisting of Original Letters, Poems, and Critical Observations_ (1808) and J. C. Dick’s_Notes on Scottish Song by Robert Burns_ (1908). Cook makes clear that these folio pages were an unnamed source for Dick in particular, and Cook transcribes many notes listed as garbled, unreadable, or spurious by Dick. This is page 12 of the folio, which carries on a discussion of “Dainty Davie” from page 11, as well as discussing the song “Tweedside”. “Dainty Dave” is said to recount an affair between Rev. David Williamson and Lady Cherrytrees’ daughter that occurred when Williamson was hiding from a party of dragoons (see page 11 for more). Burns reports that “A mutilated stanza or two” from “Dainty Dave” are recorded in Herd’s Collection, but that the song has “five or six stanzas” and Burns records the first of these. Burns also believes that the chorus from a song Ramsay records as “Luckie Nansie” was derived from “Dainty Dave”. For “Tweedside”, Burns states that the original is said to be a two-stanza song “composed by a Lord Yester”. Burns records the first stanza of this version of “Tweedside”.
metadata.label: Description

label: La-II-210-(9)
